As a result, the function LLS regression model in Equation (1) can be simplified to the following classic LLS regression (the proof is provided in the appendix, which can also be found in [8]):

The parameter estimation of the prognostic model consists of two steps: (i) feature extraction and (ii) regression parameters estimation. The first step, feature extraction, focuses on using the decentralized historical degradation signals from multiple users (i.e., 𝒙i⁢j⁢(t)subscript𝒙𝑖𝑗𝑡\boldsymbol{x}_{ij}(t)bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t )) to calculate the MFPC-scores (i.e., 𝜻i⁢jsubscript𝜻𝑖𝑗\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{ij}bold_italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation (3)). The second step, regression parameters estimation, uses the features from the first step (i.e., 𝜻i⁢jsubscript𝜻𝑖𝑗\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{ij}bold_italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and the historical TTFs (i.e., yi⁢jsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑗y_{ij}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation (3)) to estimate the regression parameters (i.e., β0,𝜷,σsubscript𝛽0𝜷𝜎\beta_{0},\boldsymbol{\beta},\sigmaitalic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_β , italic_σ). Since the historical data is decentralized, both the feature extraction and coefficient estimation algorithms should be federated, which means that they can use data from all the users while keeping each user’s data local and confidential. In this article, our contribution is to propose a federated feature extraction algorithm for applications with incomplete degradation signals, which will be discussed in Section 3. Regarding the second step, regression parameters estimation, we will employ the federated algorithm developed in [29].

In this section, we propose a federated feature extraction algorithm that computes the MFPC-scores (i.e., 𝜻i⁢jsubscript𝜻𝑖𝑗\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{ij}bold_italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation (3)) using the decentralized incomplete degradation signals from multiple users while keeping each user’s data local and confidential. To help understand the proposed federated algorithm, we will first review how to extract the MFPC-scores using centralized complete data (i.e., the data from all users are merged together for feature extraction) in Section 3.1. After that, the proposed federated algorithm using decentralized data will be discussed in Section 3.2.

In this section, we propose a federated feature extraction method that enables multiple users to utilize their incomplete degradation signals to compute their MFPC-scores (i.e., 𝜻i⁢jsubscript𝜻𝑖𝑗\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{ij}bold_italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation (3)) while keeping each user’s data local and confidential. Inspired by the feature extraction method and the remarks discussed in Section 3.1, we first develop a federated algorithm to detect the dominant subspace of the degradation signal matrix 𝑿𝑿\boldsymbol{X}bold_italic_X (Section 3.2.1). This provides a general set of basis vectors of the dominant subspace. Next, we propose a federated algorithm that uses the general set of basis vectors of the dominant subspace and (incomplete and uncentered) degradation signals to calculate MFPC-scores (Section 3.2.2). Figure 1 provides an overview of the proposed federated feature extraction algorithm.

Utilizing their MFPC-scores {𝒛i}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒛𝑖𝑖1𝐼\{\boldsymbol{z}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{I}{ bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and TTFs {𝒚i∈ℝJi}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒚𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝐽𝑖𝑖1𝐼\{\boldsymbol{y}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{J_{i}}\}_{i=1}^{I}{ bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, all the I𝐼Iitalic_I users can jointly train a prognostic model based on (log)-location-scale (LLS) regression. In this article, we will employ the federated LLS regression model developed in [29], which allows the I𝐼Iitalic_I users to collaboratively train the prognostic model while keeping each user’s MFPC-scores and TTFs local and confidential. The parameter estimation of the federated LLS regression utilizes maximum likelihood estimation, which is solved using gradient descent. Initially, the server randomly initializes the regression coefficients. Subsequently, each user downloads these initial coefficients and computes its local gradients using its local data (i.e., MFPC-scores and TTFs). These local gradients are then transmitted to the server, which aggregates them from all users and employs the aggregated gradients to update the regression coefficients. This updated set of coefficients is subsequently redistributed to each user for another round of updating, repeating this process until convergence is achieved. The federated LLS regression provides each user with the estimated regression parameters, which we denoted as β^0∈ℝsubscript^𝛽0ℝ\hat{\beta}_{0}\in\mathbb{R}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R, 𝜷^∈ℝK^𝜷superscriptℝ𝐾\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_β end_ARG ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and σ^∈ℝ^𝜎ℝ\hat{\sigma}\in\mathbb{R}over^ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ∈ blackboard_R (please refer to Equation (3)).

One of the limitations of the above subspace updating method is that it is computationally intensive since SVD has to be conducted on an N×(K+1)𝑁𝐾1N\times(K+1)italic_N × ( italic_K + 1 )-dimensional matrix 𝑪𝑪{\boldsymbol{C}}bold_italic_C for each update. Typically, N𝑁Nitalic_N is an extremely large number given it is the number of observations in the longest degradation signal, while K𝐾Kitalic_K is usually a small number since high-dimensional signals are often embedded in a relatively low-dimensional subspace. To address this challenge, we may decompose matrix 𝑪𝑪{\boldsymbol{C}}bold_italic_C as follows based on Equation (6):
